title: Thursday, 2nd August, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am
BE11:05am

Hello!

Nately Ahoy
Blank canvas good morning everyone
rise2010 Morning
BE11:05am

Busy morning, relatively speaking.

BE11:06am

So I've been relaxing by looking at pictures of Chukotka

rise2010 Does the BBC know something we don't? ;)https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-45037773
11:06 am
BE11:06am

Soundbuy Morning
BE11:06am

Polar bears and foxes and lots and lots of snow.

VV75 morning
Bryan Good morning, I have been informed that there will be an important operation in the car wheel market. Do you have any information about it?
rise2010 Kaz capex on Baimskaya acquisition now exceeds the market cap
BE11:08am

Chukotka's up in the right hand postage stamp of Russia. It's the wasteland Abramovich calls home, apart from all the other places Abramovich calls home.

Shrink Evening
11:08 am
BE11:09am

And it is, curiously, the brave new frontier for Kaz.

Phil Ah, I see the cryptocurrency true believers are out in force on the Krugman post today.
Kaz Minerals PLC (KAZ:LSE): Last: 644.00, down 175.8 (-21.44%), High: 760.20, Low: 631.20, Volume: 4.71m
Shrink (I've moved, you proably noticed.)
Flaneur That looks like an FTAV Captcha....
Airborne Cigar @BE - Is Chukotka your summer holiday destination? It looks like a more civilized temperature than London ATM...
BE11:10am

Which decided to pay 20% of its market cap for a completely undeveloped patch of land that Abramovich wanted shot of .....

11:10 am
BE11:10am

................... and has immediately lost 20% of its market cap.

BE11:10am

Which has a nice symmetry, I guess.

BE11:11am

So ......... Capital expenditure was guided at $5.5bn! First production expected in 2026!

11:11 am
BE11:11am

You'll remember that Kaz is also spending $1.2bn at its Aktogay project in Kazakstan

BE11:11am

What does Kaz know about Russia? .... Um .....

Grouchmonkey Morning
Blank canvas Where does Shrink call home now?
BE11:12am

There's some stuff in there about Kaz's punt coinciding with state investment into roads and infrastructure .... which currently don't exist .......

11:12 am
BE11:13am

To say this is a massive gamble is to do a disservice to other massive gambles.

BE11:13am

Hang on, though. Surely the sellside can see the bigger picture.

BE11:13am

We struggle to see the logic of a foray outside core competency. Is Kazakhstan really mined out? After several years of upside surprise on execution and strategy, we see today’s news as a major strategy misstep.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Oh.

Manxish Morning each
BE11:13am

That's Merrill, which goes to "underperform" from "buy".

BE11:13am

Chukotka is a long way (physically, politically,climate-wise) from Kazakhstan. If you grew up playing the board game Risk, Chukotka is just west of Kamchatka. We think that the success of Kaz in Kazakhstan doesn’t necessarily translate into this part of Russia.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

(I didn't play Risk. I played Kerplunk, which is why I'm not an analyst.)

BE11:14am

What's to remember also is that the deal was pre-flagged ......

BE11:14am

Various leaks in various places.

11:14 am
BE11:15am

And yet, here we are. 20% lower.

BE11:15am

Goldman Sachs:

BE11:15am

Remember with the FY17 results in February, the company in response to speculation that it was looking to buy the project had said that it was looking at different projects. The deal value then had been speculated to be c.US$1 bn. (Mining Journal).
As such, we believe today’s announcement will not be a total surprise, although some may question timing as the company is already in the process of ramping-up production at Aktogay phase 2. The c.US$436mn in cash spend together with the capex spend of c.US$5.5bn will drive up leverage, we estimate to over 3 times by FY22, assuming the capex spend starts in FY19. In our view, the company could look to bring on a partner to share the capex load.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Just to underline that .....

BE11:16am

On our estimates, net debt to EBITDA is likely to be c.2x in FY19, rising to over 3 times by FY22, assuming the capex spend starts in FY19.

BE11:17am

Caz's numbers are even worse.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

The deal had been flagged in the media (e.g. here) & as such that the announcement is not wholly unexpected although we believe it has been an overhang for a number of investors, based on our recent conversations. Baimskaya undoubtedly provides a long pipe-line of growth as highlighted by copper equivalent production ~5% pa cagr 2030 vs. 2018 compared to -2% pa currently. However, pro-forma leverage will increase materially e.g. ~3.2x by YE’22 at spot vs. ~1.1x pre, and will continue to grow into next decade ahead of first production. Furthermore, as highlighted when we downgraded our recommendation in June (see here), we believe the market will likely attractive a higher equity risk premia given Russian risk. At this stage, we also hold reservations that a project coming on-line late next decade will be a catalyst for a re-rating in the equity particularly given the company already provided steady growth, was de-leveraging and there was a potential for a re-start of shareholder returns.

BE11:18am

So if you want a dividend, ever, then tough.

BE11:18am

Morgan Stanley:

Grouchmonkey CVS Group, please
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Taking the acquisition plus $5.5bn expected capex gives $6.4bn total for the project, or $19,400 per tonne of production (330kt first 10 years). That is more than Quellaveco in Chile (Anglo American,$18.8k), but 1. is in a higher-risk jurisdiction; 2. is based on a pre-feasibility study only (Quellaveco = fully engineered with all licences); 3. is dependent on government infrastructure, which still needs to be built; and 4. assumes government tax breaks. Thus we think this purchase adds considerable uncertainty, and may be a drain on cash for the next 10 years – we do not envisage the company paying a divi for the foreseeable future. We would also ask why Koksay is not the main focus, given familiar jurisdiction.

BE11:20am

Course, as the Kims and Novachuk own just north of 50% of Kaz so they can do what the hell they want.

BE11:20am

But that's no reason for anyone else to stick around with it.

11:20 am
undefined

Okay, so we're risk off / trade wars again.

Mouselet How long can Ryanair survive selling flights for -€230 to anyone willing to survive the complaints process?

Miners getting kicked, even ignoring the ones doing stupid deals with highly scrutinised Russians.

As for what's on the tape, everything we know about the GAM story is here: https://www.ft.com...-b747-fb1e803ee64e

BE11:30am

Please use the sharing tools found via the share button at the top or side of articles. Copying articles to share with others is a breach of FT.com T&Cs and Copyright Policy. Email licensing@ft.com to buy additional rights. Subscribers may share up to 10 or 20 articles per month using the gift article service. More information can be found at https://www.ft.com/tour.
https://www.ft.com...-b747-fb1e803ee64e

GAM shares fell sharply for a second time this week after the crisis-hit Swiss asset manager halted redemptions from bond funds with SFr7.3bn in assets following the suspension of one of its top portfolio managers.

The shares dropped more than 13 per cent to SFr8.69 in morning trading in Switzerland on the news, and are down 52 per cent from their 2018 high.

The move followed GAM’s suspension on Tuesday of London-based Tim Haywood, fixed income investment director with responsibility for the unconstrained/absolute return bond strategy, after an internal probe identified flaws with risk management and record keeping procedures.

BE11:32am

All I can add to that are numbers. Here's Kepler.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Following GAM’s H1 results, we adjust our estimates after the announced
profit warning, and have taken into consideration the potential risk
attached to the suspended investment director, which potentially affects
around CHF14.6bn of assets (or CHF74m of revenues). We estimate a
conservative CHF3bn of outflows in H2 linked to the suspension. Hence
we adjust for lower revenues and a higher cost base (re-investment into
the business) resulting in an average 31% EPS adj. decline (2018-20E). No
granularity has been provided on the ongoing investigation from
management with regard to the potential outflows or the severity of the
misconduct. While the restructuring story remains somewhat intact, we
see little upside in the stock, given major uncertainties with regard to the
potential outcome of the investigation.

BE11:33am

Haywood, head of the unconstrained/absolute return bond strategy, suspended due to "some of his risk management procedures and his record keeping in certain instances" .....

andyalan10 test
BE11:33am

And that's all they're saying. Here's Vontobel.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

Our meeting with GAM CEO & CFO on 31 July shed no additional light into what exactly went wrong. Management believes that the issue is limited to one person and that it is not related to dishonesty or fraud.

andyalan10 Has the fire alarm gone off on the right?

undefined

Government one-off and central services offset a poor maritime line.

BE11:38am

With guidance reiterated. So ........... not a lot changes really. Here's RBC.

BE11:38am

Inmarsat reported 2Q results in line with consensus, once one-offs in ‘Government’ are stripped out. Guidance has been reiterated and Inmarsat has received itsfirst “inflight” revenues. In Maritime, customer trends are encouraging although revenues/EBITDA are behind expectations.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

l Revenue Group revenue (incl. Ligado) of $372m 3% above consensus ($362m). Excluding Ligado, revenue was $339m, 3% above consensus ($330m).
Stripping out $12m of revenues from Government (airtime, equipment and contractor fee) revenues were in line with consensus
l EBITDA Group EBIDTA (incl. Ligado) of $198m 7% above consensus ($185m). Excluding Ligado, EBITDA was $165m, 8% above consensus ($153m),
stripping out the above c$12m, results were in line with consensus
l Maritime: Revenue $140m 1% below consensus ($142m). EBITDA $108m 3% below consensus ($111m). FleetBroadband: -847 subs (RBC Est -650).
VSAT subs +638 (RBC est +500). The migration from $770 ARPU Fleetbroadband to $2,530 VSAT is ongoing, although VSAT ARPUs are under some
pressure as Inmarsat pushes into “wholesale/reseller” segments.
l Aviation: Revenue $60m in line with consensus ($60m). EBITDA $26m 8% above consensus ($24m). Inmarsat has generated $1.4m of revenues on its
first inflight customers (48 planes operational of 1,400 under contract).
l Government: Government revenues/EBITDA were ahead due to $7m of additional airtime/equipment and $5m related to Inmarsat moving to prime
contractor status with DoD.

BE11:38am

They're among the stale bulls.

BE11:38am

RBC Fundamental View
Having overshot to the upside in 2015 hitting a high of over £11/share, Inmarsat's stock then undershoot hitting a low of c.£3.40 before attracting an approach
from Charlie Ergen’s Echostar in 1H 2018. We believe Maritime growth is underpinned with Fleet Xpress backlog offsetting decline in traditional Fleet
Broadband, while Aviation continues to grow. We have a 725p price target.

BE11:43am

Countrywide delivered its 1H18 result with revenues down -9% to
£304m and adjusted EBITDA down -62% to £10.7m (Citi: £8.1m), marginally ahead of the guidance previously provided. Qualitative outlook commentary is that full year trading is in line with the Board’s expectations and that sales pipeline is down -9% (from -15% at 31 December 2017), with registered properties up +3%.

Excel Developer Yikes #Countrywide.
BE11:43am

Sales & lettings delivered a -12% revenue decline to £159m and an adjusted EBITDA loss of £1.8m. UK exchange volumes declined -18% versus a -12% decline across London and implied commission rates have lowered in both regions. Financial services revenues were -6% lower at £40m and adjusted EBITDA declined -16% to £7.3m. B2B revenues declined -4% to £104m and adjusted EBITDA lowered -22% to £11.4m largely led by a poor performance in new land and homes.

BE11:44am

BE11:49am

Either of the two possible outcomes – deal termination (~$18m fee) or a significant deal price cut (which the PE seller might resist as a formal auction wasn’t conducted meaning somewhat higher likelihood of a termination) – should be incrementally positive. On a standalone basis, the stock is trading on 15.9x/14.8x ‘19/20E P/E vs. past three years’ average of ~17x and an attractive 5.5%5.7% ‘18'19E FCF yield – hence still pricing in a material deal-related discount. Thus, with optionality of a better deal outcome and favorable standalone fundamentals (7% '18-20E EPS CAGR and a strong cash generation), aided by self-help measures, we upgrade the stock to OW with Dec '19-end PT of 290p (285p) offering ~12% potential upside.

Shinshin @sprout ah, understood
BE11:49am

So .........

11:49 am
BE11:49am

We believe an acquisition price of $450-500m vs. the $600m proposed currently might make the deal more palatable to investors. This lowered price would value Mondo on ~11x '18E EBITDA pre synergies vs. 13.8x currently. The lowered multiple is still much higher than 7-9x multiple that Imerys paid to buy Rio Tinto's talc assets in 2011 and will be in line with 10-12x EBITDA multiple paid
for above average chemical assets in the past two years. This reduced price, if achieved, will substantially improve deal economics

Mouselet I don't have anything remotely relevant to say about Chunghwa Telecom or the Lotte conglomerate.
BE11:50am

... or .............

BE11:50am

Elementis has strong positioning in served niche segments, especially in hectorite minebased rheology (i.e. viscosity) modifiers for Personal Care (42% of ’18E group EBIT) and Coatings (43% of ‘18E EBIT) end markets, with low cyclicality. Further, the company has been implementing various “self-help” initiatives to accelerate organic growth, improve efficiency in the business (with ~$7m target cost savings and $18m working capital improvement from ’17-20) and tidying up the portfolio. These should result in ~7% EPS CAGR from ’18-20E with a strong 50%+ EBITDA to FCF conversion.

Peel Hunt:

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Full year results are c5% below our expectations, with a
combination of the snow and a weaker than expected
performance in some recent acquisitions. The latter issue has
been resolved with application of tighter controls and so these
issues are not expected to run into the current year. The
company has also made a series of acquisitions, which will
enhance profits by c£2m. So this leaves us with the mixed
message of weaker results than expected, but upgraded forecasts.
Clearly we need to take on trust that the short term issues have
been resolved. Assuming this to be the case, then the long-term
story should be intact, particularly given the rapid industry
consolidation.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

It's Alistair Wilson, Head of Retail Platform Strategy at Zurich!

Excel Developer Howard Archer?
BE12:04pm

Alistair Wilson, Head of Retail Platform Strategy at Zurich, comments: “Speculation over a rate rise has finally come to an end. Continued low interest rates have left savers struggling to secure a return on their cash, while inflation eats away at the other side. For retirees relying on interest to supplement their income, rates are finally heading in the right direction, but they still need to rise further to make a significant difference. It could also take months before savers actually see the impact of today’s hike, as with last November's quarter of a percent increase, which has only resulted in an average 0.07 per cent rise on easy access accounts.

“Consumers should still consider what else they can do to help their savings grow. Feeding a small amount each month into a stocks and shares ISA or a pension fund is a sensible way to build a healthy sum over the years, while also protecting your savings as you go.”

nichoman i thought they'd brexit chicken out of it
